citation.article-title: Mycobacterium hodleri sp. nov., a new member of the fast-growing mycobacteria capable of degrading polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium hodleri sp. nov.

Mycobacterium hodleri (hod' le.ri. L.gen. n. hodleri, of Hodler, referring to Christian Hodler, director of the Ministry of Science and Culture of the State of Lower Saxony, Germany, and a strong supporter of natural sciences)
Gram positive, acid fast, nonspore forming, nonmotile, and rod shaped (length, 1.8 to 2.3 μm; diameter, 1 μm).
Some cells occur in V-form and in palisades.
Scotochromogenic, producing a saffron yellow pigment on Middlebrook agar and a chrome yellow pigment on Trypticase soy broth agar.
Growth occurs at temperatures between 18 and 28°C.
Aerobic and chemoorganotrophic.
Catalase positive.

Utilizes N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, L-alanine, D-arabitol, L-aspartate, D-galactose, gluconate, D-glucose, inosotol, L-leucine, 2-oxoglutarate, L-proline, putrescine, quinate, D-ribose, L-rhamnose, L-serine, succinate, and L-valine.
Fluoranthene and rapeseed oil are utilized.
Capable of cooxidizing fluoranthene with several PAHs, including phenanthrene, fluorene, pyrene, and anthracene.
Tween 80 is hydrolyzed.

Acetamide, 4-aminobutyrate, citrate, caprate, D-sucrose, glucarate, D-glucosaminic acid, 3-hydroxybenzoate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, 2-hydroxyvalarate, pimelate, phenylacetate, D-turnanose, and tyramine are not utilized.
Long-chain mycolic acids present.
The fatty acids are mainly straight-chain saturated (C14:0, C16:0) and monounsaturated (C16:0 cis-10 and C18:1 cis-9) acids.
C18:0and C20:0 alcohols and substantial amounts of tuberculostearic acid (10-methylbranched C18:0) are present.
The predominant isoprenoid quinone is menaquinone MK-9(H2).
The G+C content of the DNA is 73 mol%.
Isolated from a fluoranthene-contaminated site near Jülich, Germany.
The type strain is strain EMI2, which has been deposited in the DSMZ-Deutsche Sammlung für Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen GmbH as strain DSM 44183.
